supportStrategies: (Writing) Display sentence frame: “Are there ___ ___ in the ___?” Students fill in and write their own version based on classroom objects or SB images.
stretchStrategies: “What's in My House?” – Clue-Based Riddle Game
Students write 2–3 clues about one room in their house on paper, using “There is/There are” and room/item vocabulary.
E.g. “There are two beds. There is a mirror. What room is it?”
Classmates guess. To extend, require at least one false clue and classmates must spot it.

items: Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Often confused – Kindergarteners will tend to prefer 'it is' for everything, even though the Vietnamese is very different for the two structures

languageTransferAnalysis.section: 4. Plural forms of it is and there is:
items: Plural forms of these structures do not exist in Vietnamese. It's difficult for kids to remember to produce them, particularly because the plural element comes before the noun phrase. There are two houses
